Article Title: How DeepSeek, the Chinese competitor to American AI companies OpenAI, Google and Microsoft, solves one of the biggest 'China problem'
Article Text:
Representative image

The Chinese startup DeepSeek has unveiled a new AI system, DeepSeek-V3, demonstrating capabilities comparable to leading chatbots from OpenAI and Google. This achievement is significant in itself, but even more notable is DeepSeek's efficient use of computing resources. According to a report in NewYork Times, DeepSeek's engineers reported using significantly fewer specialized computer chips, crucial components in AI training, than their American counterparts.These chips are central to the technological competition between the U.S. and China, with the U.S. imposing export restrictions to maintain its AI leadership. However, DeepSeek's success highlights potential unintended consequences of these restrictions, as Chinese researchers have been driven to innovate with readily available resources.DeepSeek-V3 reportedly performed on par with existing market offerings in benchmark tests assessing question answering, logic problem-solving, and code generation. Remarkably, DeepSeek achieved this with approximately $6 million in computing power, a fraction of the estimated $60 million spent by Meta on its latest AI technology. This lower cost of entry broadens the field of potential AI developers, as noted by investor Chris V. Nicholson, who pointed out the significant difference between having $6 million versus $100 million or $1 billion available.While leading AI companies often utilize supercomputers with 16,000 or more chips, DeepSeek reportedly used only around 2,000 Nvidia chips. This efficient use of resources was attributed to optimized training methods necessitated by chip constraints in China.Despite U.S. efforts to restrict China's access to advanced chips, including recent regulations aimed at preventing acquisition through third countries, DeepSeek is said to leverage existing resources. The company, backed by quantitative trading firm High Flyer, had previously acquired Nvidia chips and attracted talent with competitive salaries and research opportunities. They even hire individuals without computer science backgrounds to enhance the AI's understanding of diverse subjects like poetry and performance on challenging exams.While U.S. companies continue to innovate, with OpenAI's new "reasoning" system being a prime example, DeepSeek's rapid progress, including its own impressive reasoning model, demonstrates its competitiveness, as per the report.A key aspect of this evolving landscape is open-source software. DeepSeek has open-sourced its latest AI system, sharing the code with others. This fosters global collaboration, as noted by Yineng Zhang, a software engineer at Baseten. This open-source approach gained momentum in 2023 with Meta's release of LLama. DeepSeek's contribution demonstrates that smaller players can also contribute significantly to the open-source AI ecosystem.
Article Summary: DeepSeek-V3 reportedly performed on par with existing market offerings in benchmark tests assessing question answering, logic problem-solving, and code generation. Remarkably, DeepSeek achieved this with approximately $6 million in computing power, a fraction of the estimated $60 million spent by Meta.

Article Title: OpenAI faces new copyright case in India over use of books without permission
Article Text:
What the lawsuit says

ANI accuses OpenAI of illegally using its content

Sam Altman-led OpenAI is facing a new copyright lawsuit in India. According to a Reuters report, Indian book publishers and their international counterparts in New Delhi have filed a lawsuit aimed at halting the ChatGPT chatbot’s access to proprietary content. The lawsuit was filed by Federation of Indian Publishers on behalf of the federation's members, including prominent publishers such as Bloomsbury, Penguin Random House, Cambridge University Press, and Pan Macmillan, as well as Indian publishers like Rupa Publications and S.Chand and Co.The case, initially listed before a registrar in New Delhi, will be heard by a judge on January 28.In the lawsuit, the Federation of Indian Publishers argues that OpenAI's services in India should be governed by Indian laws. The federation’s December filing claims OpenAI used its members’ literary works without permission to train ChatGPT, with evidence from publishers. They warn that AI-generated book summaries and extracts, often from unlicensed online copies, threaten their sales.Penguin Random House announced a global initiative in November to include a copyright disclaimer in its books, stating no part may be used to train AI.The report quotes Pranav Gupta, the federation's general secretary who said "Our ask from the court is that they should stop (OpenAI from) accessing our copyright content.” “In case they don't want to do licensing with us, they should delete datasets used in AI training and explain how we will be compensated. This impacts creativity,” he added.OpenAI is already facing a lawsuit in India. ANI (Asian News International), a prominent news agency alleges that the tech company used its content without permission to train its AI chatbot, ChatGPT. ANI claims that OpenAI not only utilised its copyrighted material without a lawful licence but also accused the company of attributing fabricated news stories to the agency.Globally, the ChatGPT-maker is facing a list of legal challenges from various global news organisations and copyright holders, including The New York Times and The Chicago Tribune, who have similarly accused OpenAI of using their work without authorization.
Article Summary: Indian book publishers and their international counterparts in New Delhi have filed a lawsuit aimed at halting the ChatGPT chatbot’s access to proprietary content. The lawsuit was filed by Federation of Indian Publishers on behalf of the federation's members, including prominent publishers such as Bloomsbury, Penguin Random House, Cambridge University Press, and Pan Macmillan. The case will be heard by a judge on January 28.

Article Title: Google revamps mobile search URLs for a sleeker appearance
Article Text: Google has announced a major update to its mobile search results, aimed at simplifying the appearance of URLs for a more user-friendly experience. This redesign focuses on presenting a cleaner and more streamlined look, enhancing readability and usability on mobile devices.Like all organising efforts, this one came with its challenges. “Rethinking the visual design for something like Search is really complex,” Aileen says.“That’s especially true given how much Google Search has evolved. We’re not just organising the web’s information, but all the world’s information,” Aileen says. “We started with organising web pages, but now there’s so much diversity in the types of content and information we have to help make sense of.”Previously, Google's mobile search results often displayed long, complex URLs that could be challenging to parse quickly. This change involves removing the breadcrumb element from mobile search results, which frequently got cut off on smaller screens. Instead, Google will now show only the most critical parts of the URL, such as the domain name and a simplified path.Google explained that this update is designed to make it easier for users to understand where a link will take them without unnecessary clutter. The company emphasised that this change will apply to all languages and regions where Google Search is available on mobile. Meanwhile, the breadcrumb element will still be present on desktop search results.“We hope this change makes it easier for people to find what they're looking for when they're searching on mobile,” a Google representative mentioned in a blog post. The cleaner format aims to offer a more intuitive and user-friendly browsing experience , especially on smaller screens.
Article Summary: Google has announced a major update to its mobile search results, aimed at simplifying the appearance of URLs for a more user-friendly experience. This redesign focuses on presenting a cleaner and more streamlined look, enhancing readability and usability on mobile devices. Google will now show only the most critical parts of the URL, such as the domain name.

Article Title: Kumbh Mela: 93-year-old record that Steve Jobs wife Laurene Powell's international flight at Prayagraj airport broke
Article Text:
How is Laurene Powell’s flight from Prayagraj significant

Poll What Do You Think of Laurene Powell Jobs Breaking the 93-Year-Old Record at Kumbh Mela? A Significant Moment for Prayagraj's Modernization A Historic Milestone for Indian Aviation

‘Steve Jobs wish’ behind wife Laurene attending Kumbh Mela

Steve Jobs' final gift: Hindu Guru's book

Autobiography of a Yogi

Laurene Powell Jobs , wife of Apple co-founder Steve Jobs , recently attended the Maha Kumbh Mela in Prayagraj, one of the world's largest spiritual gatherings. While health concerns prevented her from taking the holy dip in the Ganga on the event's opening day, her visit garnered widespread attention. Following her spiritual journey at the Kumbh, Laurene made headlines by participating in a historic moment.A Bhutan Airways aircraft recently landed at Prayagraj airport , carrying American billionaire Laurene Powell Jobs.After attending the Maha Kumbh Mela, she returned to Bhutan on the same plane. This marked Prayagraj's first international flight in 93 years, a historic milestone for the airport.In 1911, Henri Piquet initiated domestic commercial aviation in India, flying mail from Allahabad (now Prayagraj) to Naini. By 1931, the Allahabad aerodrome was established, becoming one of India’s first international airports, with flights to London until 1932.In a letter dated February 2 3, 1974 and addressed to his childhood friend Tim Brown, Jobs expressed his desire to attend the Kumbh Mela, a grand Hindu pilgrimage and festival celebrated by millions. He wrote, "I wish to go to India for the Kumbh Mela, which starts in April. I will be leaving sometime in March, not really certain yet." The letter, closing with "Shanti, Steve Jobs," provides a touching testament to his deep connection with Hindu philosophy and spirituality. It also includes a poignant note about Jobs having "cried many times," offering a rare glimpse into his emotional depth.The letter was recently auctioned for $500,321.50 (roughly Rs 4.32 crore).Steve Jobs' spiritual journey bought him to India when at Neem Karoli Ashram in Uttarakhand. While the saint has passed away years before his arrival, the teachings deeply influenced Jobs.The Book --written by Hindu guru Paramahansa Yogananda had a profound significance for Steve Jobs. As noted in Walter Isaacson’s biography, Jobs first read the book as a teenager, revisited it during his trip to India, and continued reading it annually. Such was the impact that his final gift to his friends was a copy of the book.
Article Summary: Apple co-founder Steve Jobs' wife, Laurene Powell Jobs, recently attended the Maha Kumbh Mela in Prayagraj, India. The event is one of the world's largest spiritual gatherings. Laurene made headlines by participating in a historic moment. She returned to Bhutan on the same plane, a historic milestone for the airport. In 1911, Henri Piquet initiated domestic commercial aviation in India.

Article Title: Mustafa Suleyman and Sam Altman are not best friends: Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff signals strains in Microsoft-ChatGPT partnership
Article Text: Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff predicting a dramatic shift in their artificial intelligence partnership. "I think it's extremely important that OpenAI gets to other platforms quickly because Microsoft is building their own AI and I don't think Microsoft will use OpenAI in the future," Benioff said, punctuating his observation with laughter.The partnership's strain appears to be evident with OpenAI's recent plans to expand its cloud infrastructure beyond Microsoft, partnering with SoftBank and Oracle on a $500 billion data center project called Stargate.Benioff highlighted the personal dynamics at play, noting the apparent tension between key executives: " Mustafa Suleyman and Sam Altman are not best friends."He pointed to their past interactions as evidence, recalling last year's Davos conference where "Sam and Mustafa were on panels together and not getting along." This personal friction coincides with Microsoft's strategic moves, including hiring Suleyman to lead its AI efforts.The partnership's foundation has gradually eroded since Microsoft's initial $1 billion investment in 2019. OpenAI's need for expanded computational resources and Microsoft's own AI ambitions have created increasing distance between the two organizations.Recent Microsoft AI announcements notably omit any mention of OpenAI, suggesting a potential strategic divergence. The tech giant is reportedly developing its own large language model, MAI-1, further indicating potential independence from the OpenAI partnership.Benioff, whose Salesforce uses OpenAI's enterprise models and has invested in competitor Anthropic, seems to relish the developing situation.
Article Summary: Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff predicts a dramatic shift in their artificial intelligence partnership. The partnership's foundation has gradually eroded since Microsoft's initial $1 billion investment in 2019. OpenAI's need for expanded computational resources and Microsoft's own AI ambitions have created distance between the two organizations.

Samsung launched its most expensive Galaxy S-series smartphone – Galaxy S25 Ultra at its first Galaxy Unpacked event of 2025 in San Jose, US. With its sleek design, powerful Snapdragon 8 Elite processor, and top-tier camera capabilities, the S25 Ultra is designed to impress the consumers. The smartphone comes with a starting price tag of Rs 1,29,999 and it packs in a lot of features and looks like a compelling buy.We got the chance to spend some time with the new Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra and here’s our first impressions of the new Samsung smartphone.Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra has borrowed its design aesthetics from its predecessor. The most expensive S series smartphone from Samsung continues the trend of refined aesthetics with a squared-off titanium frame and Gorilla Glass Armor 2. The Gorilla Glass Armor 2 on the Galaxy S25 Ultra is scratch resistant and it also provides anti-reflective glass ceramic cover the the smartphone. The design is both durable and elegant, with a slimmer and lighter build compared to its predecessors. The phone now features smoother, rounded corners, making it more comfortable to hold. The ride side of the smartphone houses the volume rockers and the power button. Apart from waking up the smartphone, the users can also use the power button to activate Google Gemini. The bottom part of the smartphone houses the USB Type C charging case, the slot for S Pen and the SIM card tray. The front is dominated by a 6.9-inch AMOLED display and the rear of the smartphone houses the quad-camera setup placed neatly in the top right corner. The smartphone also comes with IP68 rating which makes it resistant to dust and water. The overall build of Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra exudes sophistication, maintaining its status as a flagship device.Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra sports a 6.9-inch Quad HD+ Infinity-O-Edge AMOLED display. The display on the smartphone offers a variable refresh rate of up to 120Hz. The screen is protected with a coating of Corning Gorilla Armor 2 glass which makes it resistant to scratches. We really liked the display on the flagship Samsung smartphone. It offers a crisp resolution, smooth 120Hz adaptive refresh rate, and enhanced Vision Booster for vivid outdoor viewing. Samsung has further enhanced brightness levels, making it easy to view even under harsh sunlight. The colour accuracy and HDR performance ensure vibrant visuals, whether you're gaming or streaming videos.Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra is powered by Android’s most powerful and advanced chipset – Snapdragon 8 Elite. The smartphone comes in three variants – 12GB+256GB, 12GB+512GB and 12GB + 1TB. The smartphone performed well during our initial testing and we didn’t face any lag. We had a smooth experience during multitasking and gaming. Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra is backed by a 5,000 mAh battery which comes with 45W fast charging support. The smartphone also supports Qi wireless charging. Samsung claims that the smartphone can charge from 0to 65% in just 30 minutes. However, we are yet to test this functionality and the battery backup of the smartphone. The dual SIM smartphone comes equipped with an in- display fingerprint sensor and sports a quad rear camera setup.Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra runs Android 15 operating system topped with the company's own layer of One UI 7. Samsung has also confirmed that the Galaxy S25 Ultra will get seven years of OS and security updates. Coming to One UI 7, the AI integration in One UI 7 feels more intuitive, with features like natural language search and context-aware multitasking. The AI features of the OS come with a significant new look, based on a new notification system that streamlines communication with easy access from the device's lock screen. It includes Now Bar, which highlights relevant activities across various features like Interpreter, Music, Recording, Stopwatch and more. One UI 7 also reduces visual clutter and offers a simplified homescreen, redesigned One UI widgets, and lock screen which enhances the user experience. We will talk more about the software in our detailed review of the smartphone.Same as its predecessor, the Samsung Galaxy S25 Ultra also sports a quad rear camera setup. The rear camera consists of 200MP main camera with f/1.7 aperture, 50MP ultra wide sensor with f/1.9 aperture, 10MP telephoto lens with 3x optical zoom and f/2.4 aperture and 50MP periscope telephoto lens for 5x optical zoom and f/3.4 aperture. Front houses a 12MP selfie camera with f/2.2 aperture. The camera delivered some really impressive results during our initial testing. The primary sensor on the Galaxy S25 Ultra manages to capture incredible detail and dynamic range. The AI enhancements bring sharper portraits and more accurate colour reproduction. Features like depth-of-field control and Galaxy Log enhance creative possibilities and help users do much more with the camera. Also, the redesigned camera UX allows more intuitive control over advanced settings. Camera buttons, controls, and modes have been reorganised to make it easier to find the features you need and to give you a clearer preview of the picture you’re taking or the video you're recording. For the detailed camera analysis, you will have to wait for our detailed review.Overall, the Galaxy S25 Ultra feels like a refined iteration of an already impressive formula. Its snappier UI, AI enhancements, and polished design make it a top contender in the flagship smartphone segment. The smartphone offers a sleek design and all the high-end and powerful specifications. But will that be enough? Wait for our detailed review to find out more.

Article Title: Coca-Cola Foundation, UNDP collaborate to tackle plastic waste crisis in Asia
Article Text:
What’s the initiative is all about

The Coca-Cola Foundation (TCCF) and the United Nations Development Programme ( UNDP ) are joining forces to tackle the escalating plastic waste crisis in Asia . With a grant of $15 million (nearly Rs 130 crore) from TCCF, this three-year program will be implemented across nine countries: Bangladesh, Bhutan, Cambodia, India, Maldives, Nepal, Philippines, Sri Lanka, and Vietnam.Launched in India on Thursday (December 22), the initiative aims to revolutionise plastic waste management practices.This includes promoting recycling, minimising plastic pollution, developing country-specific solutions, and fostering regional cooperation.By sharing best practices and encouraging policy changes, the program seeks to reduce and ultimately eliminate disposable plastic, while also improving the livelihoods of waste workers.“By adopting and disseminating best practices across the region, the programme aims to inspire policy changes and community-level actions to reduce and help to eliminate disposable plastic and improve the livelihoods of waste workers,” TCCF said in a statement.Carlos Pagoaga , president of The Coca-Cola Foundation emphasised that the partnership with UNDP will focus on advancing solutions to minimise packaging waste, improve collection methods, and enhance processing capabilities.“Collaboration is key to help improve waste management systems and strengthen recycling infrastructure,” Pagoaga added.Meanwhile, Christophe Bahuet, UNDP deputy regional director for Asia and the Pacific, highlighted the region’s commitment to combating plastic waste through circular economy principles.“Across Asia, countries are combating the problem by embracing the circular economy. Through our Zero Waste and Plastics initiatives, we are helping them craft policies, attract investments, and reduce the consumption of single-use plastics,” Bahuet added.
Article Summary: The Coca-Cola Foundation (TCCF) and the United Nations Development Programme ( UNDP ) are joining forces to tackle the escalating plastic waste crisis in Asia. The three-year program will be implemented across nine countries: Bangladesh, Bhutan, Cambodia, India, Maldives, Nepal, Philippines, Sri Lanka, and Vietnam.

Article Title: Elon Musk’s $44 billion Twitter purchase: How banks may see a way out of the deal
Article Text:
What Elon Musk has to say

Wall Street banks are reportedly preparing to sell up to $3 billion in debt tied to X, the social media platform owned by Elon Musk. Morgan Stanley bankers have reportedly reached out to investors ahead of a planned sale next week.Citing sources familiar with the matter, The Wall Street Journal reported that the banks expect to recover 90 to 95 cents on the dollar.The publication initially disclosed details of the sale preparations.The report noted that to successfully sell the debt, bankers will need to persuade investors that the company’s financial situation has stabilised. Musk’s recent rise in influence and his alliance with President Trump appear to have shifted the narrative around X’s prospects, it added.Investors have reportedly been approaching the banks, expressing interest in purchasing the company’s debt due to a belief that its financial performance is improving, a source familiar with the matter told WSJ.Reportedly, in a January email to employees, Musk highlighted the company’s increasing influence and power but acknowledged ongoing financial challenges.“Our user growth is stagnant, revenue is unimpressive, and we’re barely breaking even,” he reportedly said in the email.However, Musk has denied the report, calling it “false” in a post on X, accusing the newspaper of “lying.”“This report is false. I sent no such email. WSJ is lying,” Musk said.Morgan Stanley, Bank of America, and Barclays were among the institutions that lent Musk funds to facilitate his $44 billion acquisition of X, formerly known as Twitter, in 2022.Typically, banks sell loans to investors shortly after a deal closes, however, offloading X-related debt has proven challenging. Musk's significant restructuring of the platform, which included widespread layoffs of moderation staff and controversial posts that alienated advertisers, resulted in declining revenues. This, in turn, diminished the debt’s value due to heightened default risk.
Article Summary: Morgan Stanley bankers have reportedly reached out to investors ahead of a planned sale next week. The Wall Street Journal reported that the banks expect to recover 90 to 95 cents on the dollar. Morgan Stanley, Bank of America, and Barclays were among the institutions that lent Musk funds to facilitate his $44 billion acquisition of X.

Article Title: Sheryl Sandberg: Just days after being dumped by Mark Zuckerberg, former Meta COO Sheryl Sandberg gets court notice for 'using Gmail' and deleting emails
Article Text:
Former Meta COO Sheryl Sandberg

Poll Should Personal Email Use Be Restricted in High-Ranking Positions? No, It’s a Personal Choice Yes, It Could Lead to Security Risks

What the shareholders have to say

Meta's former COO, Sheryl Sandberg , faces escalating challenges. Days after Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg reportedly attributed the company’s controversial policies to her, a new legal case has emerged. According to a New York Times report, Zuckerberg criticized Sandberg for Facebook’s current “culture” and inclusivity efforts during a meeting with Stephen Miller, a senior advisor to former President Donald Trump.Sandberg has now reportedly been sanctioned by a Delaware judge for allegedly deleting emails related to the Cambridge Analytica scandal.According to a report in Tech Crunch, this stems from a shareholder lawsuit filed late last year against Sandberg and former Meta board member Jeff Zients.The shareholders allege that Sandberg and Zients used personal email accounts to discuss matters related to a 2018 lawsuit accusing Facebook leaders of violating the law and their fiduciary duties regarding user privacy. They further claim that Sandberg and Zients deleted emails from these personal accounts despite a court order not to. The judge found these allegations credible.The judge's decision states that Sandberg used a personal Gmail account under a pseudonym for communications relevant to the case. The judge also noted inconsistencies in Sandberg's responses to interrogatories and plaintiffs' questions, suggesting she selectively deleted emails rather than using an auto-delete function.As a sanction, the judge has raised the burden of proof for Sandberg's affirmative defense. She must now prove her defense with "clear and convincing" evidence, a higher standard than the usual "preponderance" of evidence. The judge also awarded certain expenses to the plaintiffs.A spokesperson for Sandberg maintains that the plaintiffs' claims are without merit, stating that "all work emails were preserved on Facebook’s servers."The underlying issue involves allegations that Meta violated a 2012 FTC order prohibiting the company from collecting and sharing user data without consent. Facebook allegedly sold data to commercial partners, including Cambridge Analytica, and removed required disclosures from privacy settings. Meta previously paid a $5 billion fine to the FTC in 2019 for violating this order and has also faced penalties from European regulators.
Article Summary: Sheryl Sandberg has reportedly been sanctioned by a Delaware judge for allegedly deleting emails related to the Cambridge Analytica scandal. This stems from a shareholder lawsuit filed late last year against Sandberg and former Meta board member Jeff Zients. The underlying issue involves allegations that Meta violated a 2012 FTC order prohibiting the company from collecting and sharing user data.

Article Title: Gadgets Now Awards 2024 jury meet: “It was really a difficult task to choose the winner”, says CP Gurnani
Article Text:
CP Gurnani’s “dil mange more” moment

Which innovation impressed CP Gurnani the most

CP Gurnani on AI

Pankaj Mohindroo

Prasanto Kumar Roy

Paavan Nanda

Prasad Sanyal

The Gadgets Now Awards 2024 witnessed a gathering of leading technological minds who assembled to perform a comprehensive review of the year's most impressive digital innovations. This distinguished panel, composed of influential figures in the technology industry, conducted a thorough examination of the current state of technological advancement.A key member of this esteemed jury was CP Gurnani , the co-founder and executive vice chairman of AIonOS.Gurnani, a visionary leader in the field of technological innovation, offered invaluable strategic insights during the evaluation process. While participating in the jury meeting, Gurnani expressed his admiration for the remarkable innovation demonstrated by the showcased products, noting that selecting a winner from such a competitive pool proved to be a challenging endeavor.“You know, on one end, I would say.. an amazing product range. Clearly when it came to innovation in design, innovation in features, innovation led by AI, and the power of the chipsets. It was really a difficult task to choose the winner,” Gurnani told the Times of India-Gadgets Now team.Gurnani expressed a desire for even more ambitious and impactful innovation, particularly in the area of environmental sustainability.“But you know, there's always this “dil mange more” moment. And I would have been happy if it was a green innovation contest. For me, the dream would be, ‘every gadget that we ever sell or supply in Delhi, should come in with those miniaturised air purifiers. If you can convert a watch into a phone; And if you can convert a phone into a TV studio. I don't see a reason why we cannot dream big and think of features, which are more software-driven, more electronics-driven and can be miniaturised,” he added.Gurnani analysed the innovation seen in different gadget categories, highlighting both progress and areas needing further development.“Clearly every category has got its own range of innovation or maturity of innovation. For example, the foldable category – whether it was the Flip or the fold category, the level of integration of hardware software, and the sophistication of hardware is very impressive, the form factor is becoming better and more importantly, the weight of the device has become a lot better,” he said.“Similarly, in the desktops or in the laptop categories, the power of the chip, the power of a gaming console or a PC console, becoming similar and even the power of not only the laptops but also that you could do a multi-fold screen right on the same device, I think it is a great innovation,” Gurnani noted.“Number three on the devices, whether it was the robotics or whether it was small improvements of noise cancellation on the earbuds, I think there is a definitive progress. AI will come into the use cases. Hopefully the medical devices industry will die as the camera industry died. At one stage, because if all your testing can be done on your smartwatch or your phone, I don't see any reason why a CT scan cannot be done through one of the devices,” he added.Other jury members included, chairman of the India Cellular & Electronics Association (ICEA), who lent his expertise on manufacturing and market trends, offering a crucial perspective on the industry's trajectory., technology advisor at FTI Consulting, contributed decades of experience in technology journalism to the panel's deliberations., CEO of WinZO Games, enriched the discussion with his specialised knowledge of digital entertainment and gaming technologies., Business Head of Times Internet Ltd, lent his keen acumen to the jury, providing a crucial analytical perspective to the selection process.The Jury meet was moderated by Manisha Singh, editor, TOI Tech.The winners for the Jury's Choice Awards, along with the Popular Choice Awards—for which voting is open until February 7, 2025 – will be announced on February 14.

Article Title: Ai Pets For Children In China: China’s young generation turns to AI pets for emotional support
Article Text:
AI pets offer comfort and connection for young people facing social anxiety in China

Smart AI pets gain popularity among families in China

A quirky new trend sweeping China is young people turning to AI pets for comfort and companionship. These virtual creatures, designed to interact with their owners, are providing a unique form of support, especially for those who struggle with social anxiety. With their lifelike personalities and comforting presence, AI pets are offering a much-needed escape from the pressures of daily life.Whether for a chat, a playful moment, or just a calming presence, these digital friends are helping to fill an emotional gap for many. As the popularity of AI pets grows, they're becoming an interesting part of the conversation about technology and mental well-being, one purr or wag at a time.Smart Artificial Intelligence (AI) pets are increasingly popular in China, where young people are seeking digital companions to help them cope with social anxiety and emotional support, as per the reports of South China Morning Post. Since May 2024, BooBoo, a fuzzy and wriggly "smart pet" that looks like a guinea pig, has sold more than 1,000 units. One user, 19-year-old Zhang Yachun, shared how her AI pet, named "Aluo," has made her life easier. She struggled with building lasting friendships and now finds comfort in her virtual companion, which she treats to winter clothes.With such exponential growth, according to experts, the global social robots market will increase sevenfold by 2033 and reach $42.5 billion. For a lot of families, smart AI pets have now become a great source of emotional support and, in some aspects, help to offset the growing number of lonely city lives.The demand for such robot pets is reported to increase with Weilan, the leading supplier of AI pets as BabyAlpha, that 70% of their customers are families with young children. These four-legged robos cost between 8,000 to 26,000 yuan and tend to be an investment for those seeking emotional support and interactive companionship for their children.While AI pets are increasingly common among the younger generation, they appeal to more than just children. Families have also bought these robotic friends to aid in various activities and comfort their loved ones. According to 33-year-old Guo Zichen, AI pets come in handy when his child is unable to spend quality time with him. He believes they will be very helpful to children, especially when studying and other activities are concerned. However, he also stressed that these AI pets cannot replace the real ones.
Article Summary: Smart Artificial Intelligence (AI) pets are increasingly popular in China. Young people are seeking digital companions to help them cope with social anxiety and emotional support. Article Title: Elon Musk 'clarifies' no money comment to Satya Nadella, Microsoft CEO responds

Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella responds

Where it all started

Article Title: Samsung president takes aim at Chinese smartphone companies; says there are 'trust issues'
Article Text:

Park reportedly acknowledged the rapid adoption of AI by Chinese brands but emphasized the "trust factor," posing the question of whether these brands are truly trustworthy with sensitive user data.Park admitted that Samsung is unlikely to win every battle in every price segment but reiterated the company's commitment to meeting Indian consumer needs through differentiated products, with AI playing a crucial role. He likened the current stage of AI development to the early days of the internet, emphasizing the unpredictable nature of its future.To further reach consumers, particularly in rural areas, Samsung plans to double its service center network to 800 by the end of 2025. This initiative aims to provide hands-on experience with the latest mobile technologies, including AI, which Park believes is crucial given the limitations of online experiences.Samsung launched the new flagship phones in three variants: Galaxy S25 Ultra, Galaxy S25+ and Galaxy S25. The new phones have a customized Snapdragon 8 Elite Mobile Platform for Galaxy chipset. Samsung also plans to launch an ultrathin version of Galaxy S25 phone in the first half of this year. Called Samsung S25 Edge, it will add a fourth model to its newly unveiled flagship Galaxy S25 family of devices.While speaking about Galaxy S25, Park said: “We will also manufacture the new Galaxy S25 series at our Noida plant in India.”“We are confident that Galaxy S25 will prove to be more popular than its S24 series,” he added. According to Park: “In fact, Indian consumers are the biggest users of Galaxy AI features such as circle to search and call assist.”
Article Summary: JB Park, President and CEO of Samsung Southwest Asia, suggested that Indian consumers need to consider which brands they can reliably entrust with their private information. Article Title: Pakistan lawmakers to Elon Musk: Apologise first, then seek approval
Article Text:
Elon Musk

Pakistani Senators Demand Apology from Elon Musk , Accusing Him of "Anti- Pakistan Propaganda" Amid Starlink 's License Application. Starlink, Musk's satellite internet service, has applied for regulatory approval to operate in Pakistan but awaits clearance. A Senate committee on IT and telecommunications recently convened to review the application, a lawmaker informed AFP.Committee chair Palwasha Mohammad Zai Khan told AFP that several senators condemned Musk's recent comments on his social media platform, X, which they deemed "anti-Pakistani." These comments relate to Musk's repeated highlighting of claims that men of Pakistani origin were involved in historical child sexual abuse cases in England, primarily targeting white girls.Khan stated that the committee discussed recommending approval of Starlink's license on the condition of an apology from Musk. She clarified, "We are not saying it should be a pre-condition, but it was a part of the discussion, and we can only give our recommendations to the government."Musk's criticism began earlier this month, targeting the UK government's initial reluctance to hold a national inquiry into these abuse cases. One prominent case involved the sexual exploitation of at least 1,400 girls in Rotherham over a 16-year period. Subsequent investigations and court cases resulted in the conviction of numerous men, many of South Asian descent.The issue resurfaced after an Indian lawmaker posted on X on January 8, stating, "They aren't ASIAN Grooming Gangs but PAKISTANI grooming gangs. Why should Asians take the fall for one absolute rogue nation?" Musk responded with "True."These historical abuse cases are a sensitive topic in the UK, with some arguing they are exploited to fuel Islamophobia, while others contend that open discussion is suppressed.Beyond his business ventures in electric vehicles and space exploration, Musk has recently become more politically active, particularly aligning himself with figures in US politics.
Article Summary: Pakistani Senators Demand Apology from Elon Musk. Accusing him of "Anti- Pakistan Propaganda" amid Starlink's License Application. Starlink, Musk's satellite internet service, has applied for regulatory approval to operate in Pakistan.

What is the ANI-OpenAI case all about

ChatGPT-maker OpenAI has challenged Delhi High Court 's (HC) jurisdiction in a copyright lawsuit filed against the tech giant in November brought by news agency ANI . The Microsoft-backed company has argued that the court lacks jurisdiction as OpenAI had no presence in the country.In its filing, OpenAI stated that complying with ANI's request to remove its data from ChatGPT 's training would violate its legal obligations in the United States, news agency Reuters said in a report.OpenAI "is therefore under a legal obligation, under the laws of the United States to preserve, and not delete, the said training data", it said.The company added that it has "no office or permanent establishment in India ... the servers on which (ChatGPT) stores its training data are similarly situated outside of India".ANI has countered OpenAI's arguments, asserting that the Delhi High Court has the jurisdiction to hear the case.ANI alleged that OpenAI used its content without permission to train ChatGPT. OpenAI maintains that its use of publicly available data for training its AI models falls within the scope of fair use.During a November hearing, OpenAI told the Delhi court it would not use ANI's content anymore but the news agency argued its published works were stored in ChatGPT's memory and should be deleted.This lawsuit follows a wave of similar legal challenges faced by OpenAI and other AI companies, including the prominent case brought by The New York Times.Furthermore, OpenAI has entered into content licensing agreements with several major news organizations, including Time magazine, the Financial Times, and Axel Springer. This has raised concerns for ANI, who argue that these partnerships create an unfair competitive advantage for OpenAI.ANI has also accused OpenAI of reproducing verbatim or substantially similar extracts of their work within ChatGPT's outputs.
Article Summary: ChatGPT-maker OpenAI has challenged Delhi High Court's jurisdiction in a copyright lawsuit filed against the tech giant in November brought by news agency ANI. The Microsoft-backed company has argued that the court lacks jurisdiction as OpenAI had no presence in the country.

Article Title: GenAI to transform 38 million jobs by 2030: EY India
Article Text: EY India recently shared a report titled “How much productivity can GenAI unlock in India? The AIdea of India: 2025,” projects significant economic gains from AI adoption by 2030. The report forecasts that AI could transform 38 million jobs, leading to a 2.61% productivity boost in the organized sector. This potential could further increase to 5.43% with broader Generative AI or Gen AI adoption in the unorganized sector.The findings are based on a survey of over 125 C-suite executives, highlighting the urgent need to address the skills gap to fully realize the potential of AI in India.As per the report, GenAI's transformative power is evident across various job roles, with the potential to automate 24% of tasks and enhance 42% through AI augmentation. This translates to a potential time-saving of 8-10 hours per week for knowledge workers. While the services sector is projected to experience the most significant productivity gains due to its labor-intensive nature, manufacturing and construction are also expected to benefit.The report underscores the critical role of talent in successful AI adoption. According to it, a mere 3% of Indian enterprises possess the necessary in-house talent and resources, while 97% of executives identify talent shortages as a major obstacle.Anand Mahurkar, CEO, Findability Sciences said “EY's report on GenAI transforming 38 million jobs by 2030 underscores the urgency for businesses to adopt innovative AI-driven solutions. At Findability Sciences, we are leading this charge with our latest breakthrough—the Agentic Workflow Engine—alongside Enterprise Forecasting and Business Process CoPilots. These advancements empower organizations to automate workflows, enhance decision-making, and achieve tangible ROI. Our Agentic Workflow Engine exemplifies how GenAI can unlock unprecedented productivity, enabling businesses to not just adapt to change but thrive in the face of it. Together, we are driving the future of work, where AI and human ingenuity converge.”

Article Title: MakeMyTrip posts record breaking numbers for Q3, revenue up by 26.2% y-o-y
Article Text:
MakeMyTrip

MakeMyTrip announced a record quarterly revenue of $267.4 million, a 26.2% surge year-over-year. Gross bookings for the quarter reached $2.61 billion, reflecting strong demand across air, hotel, and other travel segments. Adjusted operating profit also saw substantial growth, reaching $46.0 million compared to $33.4 million in the same period last year."The Indian travel and tourism sector is witnessing robust growth, reflecting a strong desire among travelers to explore new horizons," said Rajesh Magow, Group Chief Executive Officer, MakeMyTrip."While Indian destinations continue to shine, many countries have made significant efforts to attract Indian travelers. Our strong performance this quarter reflects these macro trends, along with our focused execution and commitment to customer centricity."Mohit Kabra, Group Chief Financial Officer, MakeMyTrip, said, “Our robust financial performance this quarter across all lines of business underscores our strong execution of strategic priorities and the resilience of the travel sector. Our disciplined approach to cost management, combined with targeted investments in technology and customer experience, has enabled us to capitalize on growing travel demand and drive profitable growth.”On the back of the rising air passenger traffic in India, projected to reach 480 million by 2027 according to IATA, MakeMyTrip witnessed a 20.0% quarter-over-quarter growth in its air ticketing business.

Gross bookings for the quarter reached $2.61 billion, reflecting strong demand across air, hotel, and other travel segments. Adjusted operating profit also saw substantial growth, reaching $46.0 million.
